desc.p: Lingyin Monastery sits at the foot of Mountain Wulin (武林山) right next to the famous West Lake in the northwest of Hangzhou. Throughout Chinese history, it is one of the most prominent Buddhist institutions of the Chan in the Jiangnan region. The meaning of the monastery's name is said to be “the location of retreat for immortals” (xianling suozhi 仙灵所隐) (Yang et al., 368). When Emperor Kangxi visited the monastery and bestowed a horizontal plague with his calligraphy of “Yunlin” (云林) in 1689 (康熙二十八年 28th year of Kangxi), its name was briefly changed correspondingly to Yunlin Monastery (云林寺). According to legends recorded in textual sources from Qing Dynasty, the monastery was founded by an Indian monk, known as Huili (慧理) in Chinese, that can be traced back to 326 (咸和元年 First year of Xianhe) or 328 (咸和三年 Third year of Xianhe) in Eastern Jin Dynasty (Sun and Xu, 26). The influential myth of Huili and his monkey may have inspired the emergence of the supernatural monkey hero Sun Wukong (孙悟空) in the folklore novel Journey to the West (Xiyouji 西游记) (Shahar, 194). Additionally, Lingyin Monastery was also considered the place of origin for the popular folklore legends of the eccentric Chan monk Jigong (济公) (Lv, 24). These legends contribute to the cultural richness of the site.

The destiny of Lingyin Monastery is closely associated with the shift of attitudes towards Buddhism in the imperial courts of different dynasties. In the Northern and Southern dynasties and the subsequent Sui periods, the emperors continued to patronize the monastery, developing new structures and attracting more residential monks. In Tang Dynasty, the main structures of the monastery was heavily destroyed in the Huichang Persecution of Buddhism (Huichang fanan 会昌法难). However, Lingyin Monastery ascended to its peak under the ruling of Yuezhongyi King of Wuyue Kingdom (吴越忠懿王) with new constructions of nine multi-storied buildings and 18 pavilions (Zhao and Huang, 57-8). In Song, Yuan, and Ming dynasties, Lingyin Monastery was supported by the imperial rulers and hosted large sums of visitors and monks. However, due to warfare and natural disasters such as fire and lightning, it also suffered serious damages in 1359, 1370, 1430, 1569, and, most devastatingly, in 1640 (Sun and Xu, 14). Starting in 1649 under Qing’s reign (顺治六年 sixth year of Shunzhi), Lingyin Monastery was resurrected from ruins to an unprecedented scale under the supervision of Monk Jude (具德) after a 18-year restoration. The contemporary visitors claimed that they had never seen the monastery this prosperous since its initial foundation (Sun and Xu, 3). Both Kangxi and Qianlong Emperor frequently visited the monastery during their various inspection tours in Jiangnan, leaving numerous poems, works of calligraphy and generating other folklore legends along the way (Shen, 1-25). These historic artifacts elevated the cultural significance and national fame of Lingyin Monastery to an extraordinary level.

After undergoing substantial demolition during the long years of military conflicts, natural catastrophes, and domestic persecutions from the Late Qing reign all the way to the Cultural Revolution, Lingyin Monastery eventually reopened to the public in 1970. Based on the remaining structures from late Qing dynasty, the Communist government sponsored two large projects of restoration and reconstruction, respecitively in 1975 and 1987, expanding the monastery to cover approximately 87,000 square meters (Shi, 387). The plan of modern-day Lingyin Monastery is modeled after the most common seven-hall arrangement in a Chan monastery of Southern Song China (Steinhardt, 172). Five main buildings sitting along the central axis are the Divine Kings Hall (tianwangdian 天王殿) bearing the function of the Mountain Gate (shanmen 山门), the Daxiongbao Hall (大雄宝殿) or the Treasure Hall of Mahavira, the Bhaisajyaguru Hall (yaoshidian 药师殿), the Sutra Library (cangjinglou 藏经楼) which also contains Law Hall (fatang 法堂), and Huayan Hall (华严殿). Among these, the first three halls largely remained in the same position of its Qing predecessors. According to records indicated on Lingyin Monastery’s official website, as no historic structure survived, the Bhaisajyaguru Hall was also completely reconstructed in 1991. At 33.8 meters high, the Daxiongbao Hall is the tallest hall in the monastery and has a hipped roof with three sets of eaves on top. This building experienced three major restorations in 1952 – 1955, 1975 – 1980, and most recently in 2015 – 2016 (Xia and Xia, 37). Inside, the current gold-gilded wooden sculpture of the Gautama Buddha was created in 1956 following Tang dynasty style (Shi, 386). On the other hand, built between November 2000 and October 2002, the Sutra Library and Huayan Hall were both new structures added to recreate the central axis in this seven-hall plan. The Arhats Hall (luohantang 罗汉堂), also built in 2002, faces the west side of the courtyard in front of the Daxiongbao Hall. Other important structures in the monastery include two twin stone pagodas (shita 石塔) in front of the Daxiongbao Hall, and two twin stone sutra pillars (jingchuang 经幢) made in 969 standing next to the Divine Kings Hall (Zhongguo wenwuju, 26).

灵隐寺坐落于杭州西南武林山脚，临近著名的西湖。在中国历史上，该寺一直为最重要的禅宗佛教寺院之一。寺名原意引自“仙灵所隐之处”。1689年康熙皇帝巡视江南之时在灵隐寺题赐匾额“云林”，寺名也因此更为云林禅寺。据清朝记载的传说起源，印度高僧慧理创办此寺，一说创于东晋咸和元年，一说为咸和三年。慧理与他的猴子的传说很可能也影响了西游记中孙悟空的形象。另外，民间家喻户晓的济公也可能是出家于灵隐寺中。这些广为流传的逸闻趣事均使灵隐寺广富文化盛名。

灵隐寺的命运一直与朝代更迭中统治者对佛教的态度紧紧相连。南北朝与之后的隋朝中，皇帝们一直大力支持兴建寺院、吸引众多僧侣。至唐代，寺院绝大多数的建筑都毁于会昌法难中。然而，灵隐寺在吴越忠懿王治下迎来新的鼎盛期，扩建九楼十八阁。在宋、明朝时，灵隐寺虽饱经沧桑，但在统治者支持下香火不曾断。但由于长年战争与如火灾、雷击等自然灾害的摧残下，灵隐寺经历了五次大毁，分别于1359年、1370年、1430年、1569年与最严重的一次于1640年。自1649年在清顺治皇帝治理下，具德法师广受资助，带领灵隐寺经历18年重建修缮，终于从残破旧象中重新步入兴盛。据撰写于康熙年间的《灵隐寺志》记载，“说者谓自建造以来，未见若斯之盛者也。”而之后，康熙与乾隆皇帝多次南巡驾临，留下众多诗词、墨宝于灵隐寺，也在民间产生不少传奇。这些历史遗迹使得灵隐寺更是达到了前所未有的文化知名度。

晚清至文革间，上百年战火不断，天灾频发，人心惶惶，香火摇曳。直到1970年，饱经浩劫的灵隐寺才重新对外开放。基于晚清残存的结构地基，共产党政府于1975年和1987年主持资助了两次大型修缮重建项目，将灵隐寺规模扩大到占地面积约87,000平米。现代灵隐寺的规制模仿南宋时期禅宗寺院中最常见的伽蓝七堂制式。坐落于中轴线上的五大建筑为：承担山门功能的天王殿，大雄宝殿，药师殿，藏经楼并内设法堂，以及华严殿。其中，前三个建筑物大致与晚清规制中的位置不变。据灵隐寺官网大事年表记载，因无历史结构存世，药师殿于1991年重新兴建。高33.8米的大雄宝殿则是中轴线上最高的建筑，为单层三叠重檐结构。该殿在近代展开国三次修复工作，分别在1952-1955年，1975-1980年，与最近一次的2015-2016年。殿中请放一座贴金木质佛祖释迦牟尼像，是于1956年时以唐代禅宗雕塑风格为参照而雕成的。其外，为了重新构造伽蓝七堂制式中的中轴线，灵隐寺于2000年11月至2002年十月期间全新建造了与清代规划中不同的藏书楼和华严殿。寺院中其他重要建筑包括大雄宝殿后天台上的两石塔，与天王殿前始建于969年的两石经幢。
